title: 108_s513
content: The Act is titled the "Corporate Tax Fairness and Shareholder Rights Act of 2003" and aims to prevent corporate expatriation to avoid US income tax. The definition of "domestic" for corporations and partnerships under the Internal Revenue Code is amended to specify that it refers to entities created or organized in the United States, unless specified otherwise by the Secretary. In corporate expatriation transactions, the acquiring corporation is treated as a domestic entity. The term 'corporate expatriation transaction' refers to a situation where a nominally foreign acquiring corporation obtains most of the assets of a domestic corporation, with over 80 percent ownership post-transaction. In a corporate expatriation transaction, if more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation, a lower stock ownership requirement of 50 percent may apply to a nominally foreign corporation with limited business activities. In a corporate expatriation transaction, a lower stock ownership requirement of 50 percent may apply to a nominally foreign corporation with limited business activities in the foreign country where the corporation is created or organized, and if the stock is publicly traded in the United States. The acquiring corporation must hold more than 80 percent of the stock after acquiring properties from a domestic partnership. The acquiring corporation must hold more than 80 percent of the stock after acquiring properties from a domestic partnership. Special rules apply to related transactions and stock held by members of the expanded affiliated group. The acquiring corporation must hold more than 80 percent of the stock after acquiring properties from a domestic partnership. Special rules apply to related transactions and stock held by members of the expanded affiliated group. The term 'nominally foreign corporation' and 'expanded affiliated group' are defined for this purpose. The amendment in section 1504(a) applies to corporate expatriation transactions completed after September 11, 2001, and also to transactions completed after December 31, 1996, and before September 11, 2001. The amendment in section 1504(a) applies to corporate expatriation transactions completed after December 31, 1996, but only for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF CORPORATE EXPATRIATION TRANSACTIONS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require domestic issuers to disclose the effects of corporate expatriation transactions to shareholders. This includes information on the number of employees and assets that would be located in the new foreign jurisdiction upon completion of the transaction. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 now requires domestic issuers to disclose the impact of corporate expatriation transactions on shareholders. This includes details on the assets in the new foreign jurisdiction, rights of security holders, taxation implications, and estimated tax benefits for the issuer. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 mandates disclosure of corporate expatriation transaction details by domestic issuers, including voting results and definitions of terms. A foreign entity acquiring a domestic issuer must meet certain criteria regarding the percentage of securities held by previous security holders after the transaction. The acquiring foreign entity must ensure that the securities held by previous security holders of the domestic issuer will be publicly traded in the United States and the foreign entity does not have substantial business activities in the country where it is organized. The term 'domestic issuer' refers to an issuer created or organized in the United States or under US law. Section 14(i) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 applies to corporate expatriation transactions proposed after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. MODIFICATIONS TO EXPENSING UNDER SECTION 179. The aggregate cost which may be expensed under subsection (a) for any taxable year shall not exceed $75,000 ($25,000 in the case of taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007). The phaseout threshold is increased to $325,000 ($200,000 in the case of taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007). These amendments apply to property placed in service in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
